anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment Order dated the 22nd September, 1972 of the Bombay High Court in E. P. No. 1 of 1972. M. Tarkunde, D. V. Patel, K. Rai Choudhry, K. S. Bhadti and S. L. Setia, for the appellant.

facts.text: Election to the Maharashtra State Legislative Assembly held on March 7, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: In the election to the Maharashtra State Legislative Assembly held on March 7, 1972 the 1st respondent was declared elected from Shirdi Constituency.

facts.text: 1st respondent was declared elected from Shirdi Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: the 1st respondent was declared elected from Shirdi Constituency. The appellant, a voter from that companystituency filed an election petition questioning election of the 1st respondent on two grounds one was that the successful candidate had companymitted several companyrupt practices, the other that the election, was liable to be set aside because he was.

facts.text: Appellant is a voter from Shirdi Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, a voter from that companystituency filed an election petition questioning election of the 1st respondent on two grounds one was that the successful candidate had companymitted several companyrupt practices,

facts.text: Appellant filed election petition questioning 1st respondent's election on grounds of corrupt practices and holding office of profit.

anchor.surface_text: filed an election petition questioning election of the 1st respondent on two grounds one was that the successful candidate had companymitted several companyrupt practices, the other that the election, was liable to be set aside because he was. holding an office of profit under the State Government as a member of the Wage Board for the Sugar Industry companystituted by the Government of Maharashtra under section 86-B of the Bombay Industrial Relations, Act, 1946.

facts.text: Only the ground of disqualification for holding office of profit was argued before this Court.

anchor.surface_text: The only question argued before this Court was the 2nd one. February 8, 1972 was the last date for filing numberinations and February 11, 1972 the last date for withdrawal of candidature.

anchor.surface_text: and February 11, 1972 the last date for withdrawal of candidature. The 1st respondent resigned as a member of the Wage Board on February 20, 1972 and the letter of resignation was received by the companycerned authorities on February 22, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondent resigned as a member of the Wage Board on February 20, 1972 and the letter of resignation was received by the companycerned authorities on February 22, 1972.

facts.text: 1st respondent nominated as member of Wage Board on 13th April 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The Wage Board to which the 1st respondent was numberinated as a member on 13th April 1971 was,constituted under the provisions of Chapter 12A of that Act introduced by the Amending Act No. 43 of 1948.

facts.text: Wage Board constituted by Government of Maharashtra under section 86-B of Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: office of profit under the State Government as a member of the Wage Board for the Sugar Industry companystituted by the Government of Maharashtra under section 86-B of the Bombay Industrial Relations, Act, 1946. The only question argued before this Court was the 2nd one.

facts.text: First Wage Board for Sugar Industry constituted in 1956 by notification dated March 20, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The first Wage Board for Sugar Industry was companystituted in the year 1956 by a Government numberification Development Department No. BIR-2355, dated March 20, 1956. The Wage Board companysisted of three members.

facts.text: New Wage Board for Sugar Industry constituted by notification dated May 16, 1967 consisting of five members.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification dated May 16, 1967, a new Wage Board for the Sugar Industry was companystituted companysisting of five members. By a numberification dated April 13, 1971 the 1st respondent was numberinated as a member of the Wage Board to represent the employers on the Wage Board in place of one E. V. Wikhe who resigned his membership.

facts.text: 1st respondent nominated on April 13, 1971 to represent employers in place of E.V. Wikhe who resigned.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification dated April 13, 1971 the 1st respondent was numberinated as a member of the Wage Board to represent the employers on the Wage Board in place of one E. V. Wikhe who resigned his membership. That numberification itself does number mention the terms of appointment.

facts.text: Non-official members of Wage Board paid honorarium at Rs. 25 per day of meeting.

anchor.surface_text: To the numberification companystituting the Wage Board in the year 1956 a resolution was also appended directing that the number-official members of the Wage Board should be paid honorarium at the rate of Rs. 25/per day of the meeting of the Wage Board and that they should also be allowed to draw travelling allowance and daily allowance at the rate prescribed in Scale 1  1   b  in section 1 of Appendix XLII-A of the Bombay Civil Services Rules  Vol. II .

facts.text: Members allowed travelling allowance and daily allowance as per Bombay Civil Services Rules.

anchor.surface_text: and that they should also be allowed to draw travelling allowance and daily allowance at the rate prescribed in Scale 1  1   b  in section 1 of Appendix XLII-A of the Bombay Civil Services Rules  Vol. II . Such a resolution regarding honorarium and allowances payable to the members was number part of the 1967 numberification creating a.new Wage Board, but apparently the members are paid only on the basis of the 1956 resolution.

facts.text: No dispute that daily allowance and travelling allowance do not make membership an office of profit.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that the daily allowance and travelling allowance payable to the members would number make the membership of the Wage Board an office of profit.

facts.text: Court held that membership of Wage Board is an office under the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that in this case the office of the membership of the Wage Board should be deemed to have been held by the 1st respondent under the Government of Maharashtra.

facts.text: Dispute whether the office was an office of profit.

anchor.surface_text: This proposition was number seriously disputed by the 1st respondent. The only serious dispute is whether that office was an office of profit.

facts.text: 1st respondent entitled to daily allowance of Rs. 18 regardless of meeting location.

anchor.surface_text: The daily allowance is number payable for a halt upto six hours, and for halt exceeding six hours but less than 12 hours only half the daily allowance was payable. The daily allowance was Rs. 18/- whether the meeting was held at Bombay, Poona, Aurangabad or Kopargaon.

facts.text: 1st respondent's evidence: spent Rs. 20 taxi, Rs. 25 food, Rs. 40 lodging when attending meetings in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondents evidence was that when he came to Bombay for attending the meetings of the Wage Board, he had to spend Rs. 20/- as taxi fare, Rs. 25/- for break-fast, lunch and dinner and Rs. 40/ for lodging, that if he had a single room for the stay in a hotel he used to pay Rs. 30/- per day.

facts.text: Hotel charges: common room Rs. 15-16, single room Rs. 28-30 per day including lodging and boarding.

anchor.surface_text: He seems to have been staying in a modest hotel which charged Rs. 15/- to Rs. 16/for a companymon room and Rs. 28/- to Rs. 30/- for a single room including lodging and boarding charges.

facts.text: Bombay High Court accepted 1st respondent's evidence on expenses and concluded payments not sufficient for profit.

anchor.surface_text: After an elaborate discussion of all the evidence, the learned Judge accepted the evidence of the 1st respondent that he had to spend Rs. 20/- for taxi fare, that in the hotel where the 1st respondent stayed the charges for a companymon room were Rs. 15/- to Rs. 16/- and for a single room Rs. 28/- to Rs. 30/per day including lodging and boarding and that if regard be had to these figures then the aggregate of the honorarium and the daily allowance payable to the 1st respondent was hardly sufficient to meet the personal expenditure incurred for the purpose of attending the meeting in Bombay,

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed with High Court's conclusion that 1st respondent did not hold office of profit.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the learned Judges companyclusion. The question has to be looked at in a realistic way.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the. appeal is dismissed with companyts. The L.P.  Civil  No.

anchor.surface_text: The Wage Board to which the 1st respondent was numberinated as a member on 13th April 1971 was,constituted under the provisions of Chapter 12A of that Act introduced by the Amending Act No. 43 of 1948.

Under section 86C the State Government may make reference to the Wage Boards for decision of any industrial matter of industrial dispute. Under section 86G the order or decision of the Wage Board is made appealable to the Industrial Court. The parties on whom the order or decision of the Wage Board is binding are enumerated in section 86H.

concepts.interpretation: These provisions demonstrate government control and judicial nature of Wage Board functions

anchor.surface_text: This Court in several decisions had laid down the tests for finding out whether an office in question is an office under a Government and whether it is an office of profit. Those tests are 1 Whether the Government makes the appointment 2 Whether the Government has the right to remove or dismiss the holder 3 Whether the Government pays the remuneration 4 What are the functions of the holder?

concepts.interpretation: Membership satisfies tests 1,2,4,5; test 3 deferred to profit analysis

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ointment at their discretion and payment from out of Government revenue are important factors in determining whether that person is holding an office

concepts.unlisted_description: Five-factor test: appointment, removal, remuneration, functions, control

anchor.surface_text: The first question to be decided is whether the membership of the Wage Board is an office under the State Government. In Maulana Abdul Shakur v. Rikhabchand Anr. 1958 SCR 387 394 this Court held The power of the Government to appoint a person to an office of profit or to continue him in that office or revoke his appointment at their discretion and payment from out of Government revenue are important factors in determining whether that person is holding an office of profit under the Government.

anchor.surface_text: It is contended on behalf of the appellant that item 11 specifically lays down that the compensatory allowance shall mean the travelling allowance, the daily allowance or such other allowance which is paid to the holder of the office for the purpose of meeting the personal expenditure in attending the meeting of the committee or body or in performing any other function as the holder of the said office, and honorarium which is not mentioned there cannot be brought within the meaning of the words such other allowance found in that item as it is not an allowance.

arguments.claim: Honorarium and daily allowance together do not constitute profit when viewed realistically as covering actual modest expenses

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the learned Judges conclusion. The question has to be looked at in a realistic way. Merely because part of the payment made to the 1st respondent is called honorarium and part of the payment daily allowance, we cannot come to the conclusion that the daily allowance is sufficient to meet his daily expenses and the honorarium is a source of profit.

arguments.claim: Mahadeo v. Shantibhai is distinguishable as no expenses incurred there unlike here

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider that the decision of this Court in Mahadeo v. Shantibhai 1969 2 SCR 422 is at all helpful to the appellant. There the successful candidate was appointed by the Railway to watch cases coming up for hearing against Railway in the various courts and give timely intimation of the same and if no instructions regarding any particular case were received by him he was expected to appear in the court and obtain an adjournment. He was to be paid Rs. 5/- for every such adjournment.

anchor.surface_text: There is nodoubt that in this case the office of the membership of the Wage Board should be deemed to have been held by the 1st respondent under the Government of Maharashtra.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied five-factor test from precedents (appointment by govt, removal power, functions performed for govt, govt control); remuneration analysis deferred; satisfied all tests except deferred remuneration.

holdings.text: the office of the membership of the Wage Board satisfies all the tests here laid down.

anchor.surface_text: Again, leaving aside for the present the question of payment of remuneration, the office of the membership of the Wage Board satisfies all the tests here laid down.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit application of established tests for office under government to Wage Board membership.

holdings.text: There can, therefore, be no doubt that the 1st respondent did hold an office under the Government.

precedents.citation: Maulana Abdul Shakur v. Rikhabchand Anr.  1958 SCR 387 394

anchor.surface_text: Maulana Abdul Shakur v. Rikhabchand Anr.  1958 SCR 387 394

precedents.cited_proposition: The power of the Government to appoint a person to an office of profit or to continue him in that office or revoke his appointment at their discretion and payment from out of Government revenue are important factors in determining whether that person is holding an office of profit under the Government.

anchor.surface_text: Ramappa v. Sangappa  1959 SCR 1167

precedents.cited_proposition: An office has to be held under someone for it is impossible to conceive of an office held under noone. The appointment being by the Government, the office to which it is made must be held under it, for there is noone else under whom it can be held.

precedents.citation: Gurugobinda Basu V. Sarkari Prasad Ghosal Ors. 1964 4  SCR 3111

anchor.surface_text: Gurugobinda Basu V. Sarkari Prasad Ghosal Ors. 1964 4  SCR 3111

precedents.case_name: Gurugobinda Basu v. Sarkari Prasad Ghosal
precedents.cited_proposition: For holding an office of profit under the Government a person need not be in the service of the Government and there need not be any relationship of master and servant between them.
precedents.cited_holding: Comptroller and Auditor General held to be holder of office of profit under Government of India.

precedents.citation: Shivamurthy Swami v. Agadi Sanganna Andanappa 1971  3  SCC 870

anchor.surface_text: Shivamurthy Swami v. Agadi Sanganna Andanappa 1971  3  SCC 870

precedents.case_name: Shivamurthy Swami v. Agadi Sanganna Andanappa
precedents.cited_proposition: Indicia of office of profit under Government: held under Government with pay, salary, emoluments or allowance attached. Tests: (1) Government appoints; (2) right to remove; (3) pays remuneration; (4) functions for Government; (5) control over functions.

precedents.citation: Ravanna Subanna v. S. Kaggeerappa  AIR 1954 SC 653

anchor.surface_text: Ravanna Subanna v. S. Kaggeerappa  AIR 1954 SC 653

precedents.cited_proposition: Fee for each sitting inferred not as remuneration but for out-of-pocket expenses. Profit connotes pecuniary gain; amount may be material to decide if profit.
precedents.cited_holding: Rs. 6/- sitting fee for Chairman of Taluk Development Committee not profit.

precedents.citation: Umrao Singh v. Darbara Singh Ors. 1969 1  SCR 421

anchor.surface_text: Umrao Singh v. Darbara Singh Ors. 1969 1  SCR 421

precedents.cited_proposition: Consolidated allowance not salary but to cover expenses without out-of-pocket; burden on challenger to prove excessive and results in profit; no evidence of excess means no profit.
precedents.cited_holding: Chairman of Panchayat Samiti's allowances not office of profit.

precedents.citation: Shivamurthy Swami v. Agadi Sanganna Andanappa  supra

anchor.surface_text: Shivamurthy Swami v. Agadi Sanganna Andanappa  supra

precedents.case_name: Shivamurthy Swami v. Agadi Sanganna Andanappa
precedents.cited_proposition: Sitting fee where alternative to daily allowance held compensatory allowance.
precedents.cited_holding: Sitting fee of Rs. 16/- per day for Khadi Village Industries Board compensatory.

anchor.surface_text: Mahadeo v. Shantibhai  1969  2  SCR 422

precedents.cited_proposition: Payment for services without corresponding expenditure constitutes profit.
precedents.cited_holding: Lawyer paid Rs. 5/- per adjournment for Railway cases holds office of profit.

anchor.surface_text: The word profit connotes the idea of pecuniary gain. In the result the. appeal is dismissed with companyts.
